climate_advice.headline: Let's find the perfect sunny, cool, and drier spot for your Achillea millefolium to thrive!

data_summary.insight: Wow, this plant really loves the sun! The data tells us it's a 'half-light plant', which means it does best in well-lit places but can handle a little bit of shade. And we can be super confident about this, since the reliability is a perfect 'match'!
data_summary.implication: This is great news! It means we should pick a spot in your garden that gets plenty of sunshine to see it flourish.

data_summary.insight: When it comes to water, your Achillea millefolium is pretty easy-going. It's described as 'moderately dry', so it doesn't need to have its feet wet all the time. The data for this is also a high-confidence 'match'!
data_summary.implication: You won't have to stress about watering constantly. This plant is tough and prefers soil that can dry out a little.

data_summary.insight: This species seems to enjoy cooler weather, just like a refreshing mountain breeze! The data points to 'rather cool montane climates' and shows it's found where average temperatures are around 8.66°C and can dip below freezing to -2.82°C.
data_summary.implication: This tells us it's a hardy plant that's not afraid of the cold. It's perfectly suited for gardens with distinct seasons.

recommendations.tip: Find a spot that gets at least 6 hours of direct sun each day. The more sun, the better!
recommendations.why: We know this with high confidence! The L value of 7.2 means it's a 'half-light plant' that thrives in bright conditions.

recommendations.tip: Plant it in well-draining soil and let the top inch or two of soil dry out completely between waterings.
recommendations.why: It's happiest in 'moderately dry' conditions (M value of 4.46), so it's much healthier when it's not sitting in soggy soil.

recommendations.tip: Don't worry about protecting it from winter cold unless you live somewhere extremely frigid.
recommendations.why: It's a tough cookie! The climate data shows it naturally lives in places where winter lows hit -2.82°C, so it's well-prepared for a chilly season.

recommendations.tip: If your summers are very hot, a little afternoon shade can be a welcome relief for this plant.
recommendations.why: Even though it loves sun, its preference for 'rather cool montane climates' and typical summer highs around 22.21°C suggests it might appreciate a break from intense, scorching heat.

avoid.tip: Do not plant it in a boggy, low-lying area where water collects.
avoid.why: This plant strongly dislikes having constantly wet roots. Its 'moderately dry' rating (M value of 4.46) is a clear sign that good drainage is essential to prevent rot.

avoid.tip: Avoid planting it in deep, constant shade, like under a dense evergreen tree.
avoid.why: To get lots of beautiful flowers, it needs sun! Its L value of 7.2 shows it's a 'half-light plant' that will become weak and sparse without enough light.

soil_advice.headline: Give your Yarrow light, fluffy soil that's not too rich, and it'll be happy as can be!

data_summary.insight: Looking at the data, Achillea millefolium, or Yarrow, isn't a fussy plant at all! It's most comfortable in soils that are 'slightly acidic to neutral'. The science agrees, showing its native soils have a pH that starts around a 'surface_0_5cm mean' of 5.91 and gently becomes more neutral deeper down.
data_summary.implication: This means you don't need to stress too much about your soil's pH! As long as your garden isn't at an extreme, your Yarrow will likely feel right at home. It's a wonderfully adaptable friend.
data_points: Ellenberg R value=5.17 (slightly acidic to neutral)

data_summary.insight: When it comes to food, Yarrow prefers 'intermediate fertility'. While our data on this preference has 'insufficient' reliability, the soil samples from its natural habitat give us great clues! They are full of life, with lots of organic matter ('topsoil mean' of 69.31 g/kg) but not an excessive amount of nitrogen. This tells us it likes a healthy, living soil, but not one that's overly rich.
data_summary.implication: This is great news for low-maintenance gardeners! Yarrow thrives without tons of fertilizer. Just focus on building a healthy soil structure, and it will find what it needs.

data_summary.insight: The structure of the soil where Yarrow grows is super interesting! It's light and airy, with a low 'Soil density' (or bulk density) of just '1.12 g/cm³' in the topsoil. It's also got a great balance of sand ('topsoil mean' of 41.61%) and clay, which means it drains well but can still hold onto some moisture.
data_summary.implication: Your goal is to create a soil that lets roots breathe and doesn't get waterlogged. A light, crumbly texture is what you're aiming for, which prevents the roots from suffocating or rotting after a heavy rain.

recommendations.tip: Check your soil's pH, but don't worry unless it's very high or low. Aim for a range between 6.0 and 7.0.
recommendations.why: Yarrow is adaptable and naturally grows in soils with a pH from 'mean: 5.91' to 'mean: 6.4' as you go deeper. It's happy in that slightly acidic to neutral sweet spot.

recommendations.tip: Mix in some compost when you plant and add a light top-dressing each spring. That's it!
recommendations.why: The plant's native soil has a good amount of organic matter ('topsoil mean' of 69.31 g/kg) but it's not super rich in nitrogen. Compost provides that slow-release goodness without overdoing it.

recommendations.tip: If you have heavy clay soil, amend it with coarse sand or compost to improve its structure.
recommendations.why: Yarrow thrives in light, airy soil with a low 'Bulk density' of '1.12 g/cm³' and plenty of sand. Improving drainage and aeration will mimic its favorite conditions and prevent root rot.

recommendations.tip: Water deeply but let the soil dry out between waterings, especially once the plant is established.
recommendations.why: The significant sand content in its native soil shows it prefers conditions that don't stay soggy. This practice encourages strong, deep roots and makes the plant more resilient to drought.

avoid.tip: Do not use lots of high-nitrogen chemical fertilizers.
avoid.why: Yarrow is adapted to 'intermediate fertility'. Too much nitrogen will give you lots of weak, floppy leaves and fewer of those beautiful flowers you're looking for!

avoid.tip: Don't plant it in a spot with compacted, heavy soil that stays wet.
avoid.why: Its roots need to breathe! The native soil is light and fluffy, with a 'Bulk density' of only '1.12 g/cm³'. Heavy, dense soil holds too much water and can easily lead to root rot.

ecological_interactions_advice.headline: Hooray! Your Achillea millefolium is a superstar for helpful garden friends!

data_summary.insight: Wow, your Achillea millefolium is incredibly popular! The data shows over ten thousand recorded visits from more than a thousand different kinds of pollinators.
data_summary.implication: This means it's a fantastic plant for supporting local wildlife! Its top visitors are mostly flies, which are super important but often overlooked pollinators in the garden.

data_summary.insight: It looks like a few different animals enjoy nibbling on your plant, especially some birds.
data_summary.implication: This is a wonderful sign that your plant is part of the local food web! The main herbivore recorded is the Greater Sage-Grouse, so unless you have a lot of them, the nibbling is likely just a little bit of sharing.

data_summary.insight: There is one main disease to watch for, a rust fungus called Puccinia cnici-oleracei.
data_summary.implication: This means we should keep an eye out for rusty-colored spots on the leaves, especially in damp weather. The data also lists some bees as 'pathogen' partners, which is unusual; they are more likely just visitors, but it's a good reminder that insects can sometimes move diseases between plants.

recommendations.tip: Let's plant more flowers with small, open blooms like dill, parsley, or alyssum nearby!
recommendations.why: Your Achillea millefolium is a favorite for important fly pollinators like Sphaerophoria scripta and Syritta pipiens. Giving them more of the flower shapes they love will keep them happy and visiting your garden all season long!

recommendations.tip: I'd suggest checking the leaves of your plant every week or two for any orange or brownish powdery spots.
recommendations.why: The data shows a specific rust fungus, Puccinia cnici-oleracei, can be a problem. If we catch it early, we can just remove the affected leaves to stop it from spreading and keep your plant healthy and strong!

recommendations.tip: Let's make sure your plant gets plenty of sun and has good air circulation around it.
recommendations.why: The data tells us this plant thrives in light and moderately dry conditions. Keeping it in a spot it loves makes it stronger and helps it naturally resist diseases like that rust fungus we saw.
data_points: L: half-light plant (mostly well lit but tolerates shade)
M: moderately dry; also in dry sites with humidity

avoid.tip: Please don't use broad-spectrum pesticides anywhere near your Achillea millefolium.
avoid.why: This plant is a hero to over a thousand different types of pollinators! General pesticides could accidentally harm these wonderful friends and disrupt the amazing little ecosystem your plant is supporting.

avoid.tip: Try not to over-fertilize your plant, especially with high-nitrogen food.
avoid.why: The data suggests it prefers 'intermediate fertility'. Even though the data for this is a little sparse, too much fertilizer can cause weak growth that's more inviting to pests and diseases.

strategy_services_advice.headline: Achillea millefolium: Your Garden's Cheerful, Tough-as-Nails Team Player!

data_summary.insight: This plant is a natural stress-tolerator! Its 'CSR strategy'—a way to describe a plant's personality—shows it's much better at handling tough conditions than it is at aggressively competing with others.
data_summary.implication: This means it's perfect for those less-than-perfect spots in your garden! It won't bully its neighbors and will thrive in places where more demanding plants might give up. It's a resilient friend.

data_summary.insight: Achillea millefolium loves sunny, drier spots and isn't fussy about soil. The 'Ellenberg indicators' are like a plant's preference list, and these scores show it enjoys plenty of light and doesn't need constantly moist ground.
data_summary.implication: You can confidently plant it in full sun and well-drained soil without worrying about watering it all the time. It's a low-maintenance sun-worshipper! The data for its nutrient preference is a little less certain, but it generally points to average soil being just fine.
data_points: EIVE Light (L): 7.2, 'half-light plant (mostly well lit but tolerates shade)'

data_summary.insight: It's a fantastic, all-around contributor to your garden's health. I love seeing all those 'Moderate' ratings for ecosystem services! It's like a reliable team member who helps with a little bit of everything.
data_summary.implication: While it's not a superstar in any single category, it consistently helps with nutrient cycling, decomposition, and even erosion protection. It's the kind of plant that makes the whole garden ecosystem stronger just by being there.

recommendations.tip: Use it as a pioneer in sunny, dry, or newly established garden beds.
recommendations.why: Its high Stress-Tolerator score (S=45.26%) and preference for sun (L=7.2) and drier soils (M=4.46) make it perfect for thriving in challenging conditions where other plants might fail.

recommendations.tip: Plant it to build healthy soil without adding lots of fertilizer.
recommendations.why: With 'Moderate' ratings for nutrient cycling and decomposition, it actively helps break down organic matter and make nutrients available in the soil. It's a self-sufficient worker for average-fertility soils.

recommendations.tip: Place it in areas that might get occasionally mown or walked on, like a meadow lawn or path edge.
recommendations.why: Its Ruderal (R=23.83%) and Stress-Tolerant (S=45.26%) traits give it the ability to bounce back beautifully from being cut back or trampled. It's tougher than it looks!

recommendations.tip: Pair it with other sun-loving perennials like grasses or coneflowers in a prairie-style planting.
recommendations.why: Its relatively low Competitor score (C=30.91%) means it coexists peacefully with neighbors, creating a beautiful, resilient, and low-maintenance plant community.

avoid.tip: Do not plant it in deep, consistent shade or in waterlogged, boggy soil.
avoid.why: It's a sun-lover (L=7.2) that prefers drier conditions (M=4.46). It will become weak, leggy, and unhappy in soggy, dark spots.
data_points: EIVE L: 7.2, 'half-light plant (mostly well lit but tolerates shade)'

avoid.tip: Don't rely on it as your primary plant for storing large amounts of carbon.
avoid.why: Its 'Low' rating for carbon stored in biomass means it's not a large, woody plant. Let it focus on its other amazing strengths, like supporting soil health and pollinators!
